explanation:
Correct calculation: The distance equals the area under the speed-time graph, which consists of two triangles. Each triangle has base 2 seconds and height \( v \). Total area = \( 2 \times \frac{1}{2} \times 2 \, \text{sec} \times v = 2v \, \text{(mph·sec)} \). Converting seconds to hours: \( 2v \times \frac{1}{3600} \, \text{hours} = \frac{v}{1800} \, \text{miles} \). Setting \( \frac{v}{1800} = 50 \), solving \( v = 25 \, \text{mph} \).

Student's error: They likely calculated \( \frac{\text{distance}}{\text{total time}} = \frac{50 \, \text{miles}}{4 \, \text{sec}} = 12.5 \, \text{miles/sec} \), then incorrectly converted to mph without addressing unit consistency: \( 12.5 \times 3600 = 45,\!000 \, \text{mph} \). However, this does not yield 100. A more plausible error is misapplying the graph’s gradient (acceleration) as speed. The first segment’s gradient is \( \frac{v}{2 \, \text{sec}} \). If equated to speed \( v \), solving \( \frac{v}{2} = 50 \) gives \( v = 100 \).

Reasoning flaw: The student conflated the graph’s gradient (acceleration) with speed itself, ignoring that distance requires calculating the area. This directly stems from misinterpreting the graphical representation of speed over time.

Distinction: This is not a scale-reading error (axes are labeled correctly) or area-shape oversight (triangles were recognized). The core issue was attributing physical meaning to the gradient instead of the area.
